description: From Middle French insidieux, from Latin īnsidiōsus (“cunning, artful, deceitful”), from īnsidiae (“a lying in wait, an ambush, artifice, stratagem”) + -ōsus, from īnsideō (“to sit in or on”), from in (“in, on”) + sedeō (“to sit”).

adjectives.description: insidious (comparative more insidious, superlative most insidious)

entries.meaning: Producing harm in a stealthy, often gradual, manner.
examples: The nurse always must be alert to signs of slow leak or insidious infiltration.

entries.meaning: Intending to entrap; alluring but harmful.
examples: All these facts clearly appear to me now to establish that the sanctioned scheme was a part of a bigger and […] more insidious scheme which was to hoodwink the creditors and to firmly establish and consolidate the position […]
The battle was lost due to the actions of insidious defectors.
